para.paratext:
Georgia' new Evidence Code retains Georgia's former approach to a testifying witness's prior inconsistent out of court statements being available for use for impeachment purposes.[
1] Thus, under O.C.G.A. § 24-6-613, a prior inconsistent statement is not hearsay, and may be used for impeachment purposes by either party.

Stubbs v. State [2] sets out the criteria that the cross-examiner must meet when impeaching a witness with a prior inconsistent statement: first, the prior statement must contradict or be inconsistent with the witness' in-court testimony; second, the prior statement must be relevant to the case; and third, the examining attorney must lay the proper foundation with the witness.

Georgia still follows Gibbons v. State ,[3] which holds that a witness' prior inconsistent statement can be used as both substantive and impeachment evidence, if the witness is available for cross-examination.

Under O.C.G.A. § 24-6-613, there is no requirement that counsel show a witness his prior inconsistent statement or admit it into evidence prior to its use for impeachment, but counsel must give the witness an opportunity to explain or deny the statement before it is introduced into evidence.[
4]

The Georgia Supreme Court has rejected the notion that a prior inconsistent statement is only admissible if the witness denies making it. The substance of the inconsistent statement may be used for impeachment even where the witness admits on the witness stand that he had made a prior inconsistent statement.[
5] A prior opinion that is contrary to the present testimony may be used for impeachment even if it would not normally be admissible.[
6]

A mere difference in the two statements made by the witness is not enough to support impeachment. Usually, the court will use the word “contradictory” in the charge to the jury.[
7] In Davidson v. State,[8] the court restricted defendant's cross-examination of a deputy sheriff in defendant's second DUI trial because no contradiction existed between the deputy's testimony at the two trials and his previous testimony was not relevant to issues at trial. A statement immediately followed by a contradictory statement which is an obvious revision of the first statement does not constitute an inconsistency which can be the basis for impeachment. In Waters v. State ,[9] the state had no grounds for impeachment when the witness testified that he had been “pulled over three or four times” and immediately revised the testimony to state that he did not know how many times he had been pulled over. In Paige v. State ,[10] the court admitted a witness's statement to police that the defendant told him that he had shot someone during a robbery because the statement directly contradicted his trial testimony. Likewise, the court permitted examination of a defendant's prior inconsistent statements where the defendant spoke to the investigative officer at the hospital, and that version of events was different than the version offered at trial.[
11]

A witness's previous contradictory statements regarding irrelevant, collateral, or immaterial matters are not admissible for impeachment.[
12]

A witness who testified by deposition, but was not available at trial for cross-examination may not be impeached by this method because counsel has no opportunity to lay a proper foundation.[
13] In Corn v. State ,[14] the state impeached a witness in a drug trafficking prosecution based on his sworn testimony during his plea that included statements regarding prior drug dealings with the defendant.

Moreover, a prior statement may be used, pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 24-6-613(b), where the witness made prior statements to the police, but later testified that she did not remember the facts at time of trial.[
15]

When an examiner seeks to impeach a witness through a prior inconsistent statement, opposing counsel may sustain the witness by proof of general good character, but may not introduce a prior consistent statement[16] unless the witness is under attack for allegedly recently fabricating his statement.[
17]

Counsel may ask a witness who has been impeached by a prior inconsistent statement at which time he was telling the truth—in court or on the prior occasion.[
18]

Before the implementation of the new Evidence Code, case law established that a witness' testimony could not be fortified or corroborated by his own prior consistent statements.[
19] In the absence of recent fabrication or improper influence or motive, prior consistent statements were considered hearsay.[
20] However, the new Evidence Code specifically addresses prior consistent statements and allows their admission if they logically rebut any attack on a witness's credibility, except for attacks upon his character for truthfulness or evidence of his prior convictions.[
21]

In Walters v. State, [22] the Court of Appeals examined a prior consistent statement offered by a victim where the trial court allowed the statement over a hearsay objection. The court reasoned that given the change in the statute, prior Georgia case law was not helpful to its analysis. It further found federal precedent inapplicable since Federal Rule of Evidence 801(d)(1)(B) differed from Georgia law at the time O.C.G.A. § 24-6-613(c) was enacted. The court looked to the advisory committee note accompanying the amended version of Fed. R. Evid. 801(d)(1)(B) because it found that under the 2014 amendment, it was similar to the Georgia statute in that they both broadened the scope of credibility attacks that can trigger admissibility of a prior consistent statement.

In this case, the defendant repeatedly questioned the victim regarding whether she stated that the defendant held a knife or a gun, and argued to the jury that maybe she didn't think she was lying, but was convinced she was telling the truth, and maybe she was just very upset over the incident. The court held that the statements were admissible because the defendant attacked the witness's credibility in ways other than with recent fabrication or improper influence, and they logically rebutted the attack under O.C.G.A. § 24-6-613(c) .

In Bolling v. State ,[23] the Georgia Supreme Court allowed into evidence videotaped statements a co-defendant made prior to a plea deal, and the co-defendant's consistent statements made at the defendant's first trial. The Court reasoned that the videotaped statements were admissible to refute the allegations of recent fabrication, improper influence, or improper motive because the recorded statement predated the alleged fabrication, influence or motive, in this case, the offer of a plea deal that the defendant was able to fully explore during his first trial.

Likewise, in Dorsey v. State, [24] the Georgia Supreme Court allowed the taped interview of a witness on re-examination, where on cross-examination, the defendant suggested the witness's statements were inconsistent. The Court reasoned the statement was admissible under O.C.G.A. § 24-6-613(c) because the witness's prior consistent statement predated the testimony at trial, and his veracity was attacked during cross.

While a witness's prior consistent statement is normally hearsay unless the witness's veracity has been questioned, the legislature has created an exception with the Child Hearsay Statute, O.C.G.A. § 24-8-820, where outcry statements of child abuse and forensic interviews are permitted; however, the statute does require that the child be under 16 at the time the outcry is made.
Robbins v. State, 300 Ga. 387, 793 S.E.2d 62 (2016).
Stubbs v. State, 293 Ga. App. 692, 667 S.E.2d 905 (2008).
See O.C.G.A. § 24-6-613; Hopkins v. State, 283 Ga. App. 654, 642 S.E.2d 356 (2007).
Johnson v. State, 289 Ga. 106, 709 S.E.2d 768 (2011).

See also Duckworth v. State, 268 Ga. 566, 492 S.E.2d 201 (1997), which explains that prior inconsistent statements are admissible as substantive evidence when the witness is present at trial and subject to cross-examination, regardless of whether the witness admits or denies making it. See also Wright v. State, 296 Ga. 276, 766 S.E.2d 439 (2014).
Griffin v. Barrett, 185 Ga. 443, 195 S.E. 746 (1938).
Campbell v. State, 231 Ga. 69, 200 S.E.2d 690 (1973) .
Davidson v. State, 284 Ga. App. 333, 643 S.E.2d 848 (2007).
Waters v. State, 210 Ga. App. 305, 436 S.E.2d 44 (1993).
Turner v. State, 331 Ga. App. 78, 769 S.E.2d 785 (2015).
Daniels v. State, 349 Ga. App. 681, 824 S.E.2d 754 (2019).
Blakely Oil & Fertilizer Co. v. Procter & Gamble Co., 134 Ga. 139, 67 S.E. 389 (1910).
Corn v. State, 290 Ga. App. 792, 660 S.E.2d 782 (2008).

Murdock v. State, 299 Ga. 177, 787 S.E.2d 184 (2016) (Court allowed the testimony of a police officer regarding statements made by the defendant's sister the day of the events to be used to impeach her, where at trial she testified she did not remember the events).
Popham v. State, 138 Ga. App. 876, 227 S.E.2d 825 (1976).
Walker v. State, 250 Ga. 230, 297 S.E.2d 33 (1982).
Davis v. State, 266 Ga. 801, 803, 471 S.E.2d 191 (1996), citing Loomis v. State, 78 Ga. App. 153, 51 S.E.2d 13 (1948).
Parker v. State, 162 Ga. App. 271, 290 S.E.2d 518 (1982).
Walters v. State, 335 Ga. App. 12, 780 S.E.2d 720 (2015) .
Walters v. State, 335 Ga. App. 12, 780 S.E.2d 720 (2015).
Bolling v. State, 300 Ga. 694, 797 S.E.2d 872 (2017).
